--- In juni=
t@yahoogroups.com, David Saff <david@...> wrote:
>
> Bruce,
> 
> This is ac=
tually a bug.  Can you log it at github?  Thanks,
> 
>    David Saff
> 
> O=
n Mon, Nov 30, 2009 at 10:52 AM, Bruce <bcowan12@...> wrote:
> > Hi,
> >
> =
> I have a problem where if I specify the java "ext" directory, JUnit is un=
able to find my test class. =A0Whereas, if I just use "classpath", everythi=
ng is fine. =A0Since my tests will ultimately depend on a number of 3rd par=
ty libraries, I really want to just use the "ext" directory approach.
> >
>=
 > For example:
> >
> > java -classpath /home/cowan/src/atst/lib/java/class=
es -Djava.ext.dirs=3D/home/cowan/src/atst/lib/java/ext org.junit.runner.JUn=
itCore atst.cs.test.TestAll
> >
> > this ends up with
> > =A0 JUnit version=
 4.7
> > =A0 Could not find class: atst.cs.test.TestAll
> >
> > The strange=
 thing is that if I use the verbose flag on java, it even logs that it succ=
essfully loaded the TestAll class from the appropriate directory before lat=
er displaying the error.
> >
> > If I modify the command line to:
> >
> > j=
ava -classpath /home/cowan/src/atst/lib/java/classes:/home/cowan/tools/juni=
t4.7/junit.jar =A0org.junit.runner.JUnitCore atst.cs.test.TestAll
> >
> > e=
verything works as expected.
> >
> > Does anyone know why -Djava.ext.dirs s=
eems to cause JUnit to malfunction? =A0(I've only tried this with JUnit 4.7=
)
> >
> > Thanks,
> > =A0Bruce
